F.

The Executing Agency

MFE, as the Executing Agency, has primary responsibility for policy planning, legislative
90.
and institutional reform, and monitoring. FD is responsible for forestry management. Both MFE
and  FD  have  satisfactorily  implemented  several  externally  funded  projects.  MFE  is  the  core
agency  for  environmental  protection  and  natural  resource  management.  MFE  has  staff  with
experience  in  externally  assisted  projects.  MFE  has  developed  the  SYIP  that  corresponds  to
part  of  the  FSMP;  proposed  promulgation  of  a  forestry  ordinance  to  implement  the  NFP;
successfully  implemented  participatory  and  community  forestry  projects;  and  is  implementing
watershed  conservation  projects.  Thus,  MFE  has  demonstrated  the  required  technical  and
managerial  capability  to  implement  a  sector  project  to  meet  the  development  and  forest
conservation challenges faced by the country.

However, MFE and FD traditional structures and procedures emphasize a top-down and
91.
centralized  approach  to  forest  sector  development  and  decision  making.  The  emphasis  has
been on protection and regulatory functions rather than improving the overall performance of the
forest  sector.  MFE  has  had  limited  impact  on  influencing  the  cross-sectoral  policies  that
adversely impact forest conservation and development. FD’s current operational structures and
practices  provide  limited  opportunity for practicing  participatory  forestry.  Furthermore,  frontline
forestry staff, who are often more in tune with the needs and challenges of forestry, have limited
decision making powers and thus often can not be proactive and innovative in their functioning.

G. 

Environmental and Social Measures

1. 

The Environment

92.
The  Project  is  classified  under  environmental  category  B.  An  initial  environmental
examination  (IEE)  was  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  environmental  guidelines.22  The
IEE  shows  that  no  significant adverse  environmental  impact  is  anticipated  and  that  a  detailed
environmental impact assessment is not required. The  IEE also  shows  that  the project design
will  improve  the  quality  of  the  environment  and  the  welfare  of  the  people  living  in  the  project
area. Among the Project’s positive contributions to the environment are (i) reduced soil erosion,
(ii)  reduced  sedimentation  of  reservoirs,  (iii)  increased  conservation  of  natural  forests  and
wildlife  sanctuaries,  (iv)  increased  coverage  of  plantation  forests,  (v)  increased  fuelwood
production, (vi) better land-use planning, and (vii) efficient land tenure rights. The summary IEE
(Appendix 9) was prepared and endorsed by the Government.

The three  core SPAs  represent  the  major  ecological  zones  in  Sri  Lanka:  the  dry  zone
93.
(Anuradhapura  district),  montane  zone  (Badulla  and  Nuwara  Eliya  districts),  and  wet  zone
(Ratnapura  district).  The  three  core  SPAs  demonstrate  the  different  degrees  and  types  of
dependence of the communities on the forest reserves that subsequently reflect their levels of
and strategies to cope with poverty.

2. 

Social Measures

The  1994  demographic  survey  recorded  676,197  people  in  Anuradhapura  dry  zone
94.
district.  Farmers  in  the  dry  zone  have  fewer  economic  alternatives  to  escape  poverty  than

                                               
22    Asian  Development  Bank,  1991,  Environmental Guidelines for Selected Agriculture and Natural Resources

Development Projects, Manila.

 24

farmers  in  other  zones.  Most  households  engage  in  shifting  cultivation  on  state  land,  which
supplies about 30 percent of household income. Income from forest products was approximately
5 percent of the total income across households. Anuradhapura District has the lowest average
household  income  among  all  districts  in  Sri  Lanka  in  1990.  The  average  monthly  household
income was SLRs2,600 ($35) compared to SLRs3,540 ($48) for Sri Lanka. The PPTA23 survey
found  that  70  percent  of  all  sample  households  receive  Samurdhi  (welfare)  payments  for  the
poor. The fluctuations in the income received by the farm households and its direct linkage with
seasonality would have made a majority of the farmer households eligible for Samurdhi benefits.
Of households sampled by the PPTA study, 38 percent were at or below the poverty line while
most farmers are just above poverty line. The 1994 survey estimates the population of 750,000
people  in  Badulla  and  671,000  in  Nuwara  Eliya  districts.  According  to  the  1990/1991  survey,
households in Badulla  and  Nuwara  Eliya  districts  earned 80-84  percent  less  than  the national
average of SLRs3,540 ($35) per month. The incidence of poverty in Badulla was 36.8 percent
and  in  Nuwara  Eliya,  22.6  percent.  In  Badulla,  36  percent  of  children  aged  3-5  were
underweight in 1993. In Walapane Division in Nuwara Eliya District, 40 percent of the children
were  underweight.  Ratnapura  District  had  917,000  people  in  1994.  Communities  near  forest
reserves  in  Ratnapura are  less dependent  on forest  products  due  to  tea  production.  The  Tea
Land Survey in 1994/1995 observed that 84 percent of the tea producers in Ratnapura District
were tea smallholders with less than 0.4 ha. The income received from tea ranged between 37
and 58 percent of the household income for those owning 0.5-1.5 ha. A socioeconomic survey
of 17 wet zone conservation forests showed that 90 percent of the households extracted forest
products for their domestic use.

95.
The full participation of women will be needed to make any changes of land use in and
around  forest  reserves.  The  Project  will  actively  seek  women’s  input  in  the  integrated  forest
resource  planning  process  through  socioeconomic  surveys  of  household  uses  of  forest
resources and  resource  inventories  carried  out by  women.  Buffer  zone  development  activities
will  invite  the  participation  of  households  that  have  encroached  on  forestlands  and  offer
assistance in tea production, leadership training, and savings mobilization.  The assistance  will
have  a  direct  impact  on  household  income  and  provide  additional  opportunities  for  women  to
participate in the market economy.

Project interventions have been designed to encourage the communities to see the need
96.
for  reducing  forest  exploitation  and  adopting  conservation  measures.  Public  awareness
campaigns will provide information on the value of local forests for (i) community water sources,
(ii)  rice  irrigation,  and  (iii)  creation  of  beneficial  microclimates  for  tea  production.  At  the  same
time  the  Project  will  demonstrate  that  additional  income  can  be  generated  through  improved
management  of  the  forest  reserves  and  long-term  investment  in  the  existing  smallholding
woodlots, tea plantations, home gardens and other cultivated land. The Project will complement
ongoing  Government  efforts  to  address  widespread  poverty  among  its  forest  communities.
Appendix 10 details the social assessment on poverty alleviation.

V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A.

Economic and Financial Analyses

1. 

Economic Analysis

Economic analysis was carried out for the three core SPAs, which  represent the  major
97.
agroecological  zones  and  are  considered  to  be  representative  of  the  wider  project  area.  To
quantify costs and benefits associated with the distinct physical characteristics of each SPA, the

                                               
23   TA 3047-SRI: Forest Resource Management Project, for $800,000, approved on 20 July 1998.

 25

major field intervention activities were grouped into (i) new agroforestry plots on encroached FD
land, (ii) management of existing  community  woodlots,  (iii)  management of encroachment  into
buffer  zones and forest  reserves,  (iv) enrichment  of protection  plantations,  (v)  rehabilitation  of
degraded  FD  plantations,  (vi)  improved  management  of  teak  and  eucalyptus  plantations,  and
(vii) pilot private sector concessionaires.  All costs and benefits have been divided into tradable
and  nontradable  components.  The  former  is  expressed  in  border  prices  and  the  latter  in  the
value  of  foreign  exchange.  The  border  prices  were  estimated  from  domestic  prices  using  a
standard  conversion  factor  of  0.9.  The  analysis  is  undertaken  using  with  and  without  project
approaches.

98.
The costs at the subproject level include those incurred in the physical development of
the  field  interventions,  including  extension  inputs,  planting  and  labor,  survey  and  lease
agreements,  and  marketing.  In  addition,  costs  of  the  intermediate  services  and  goods
(component 1) required to successfully implement the Project along with the prerequisite human
resource development and institutional strengthening (component 3) are apportioned to the core
SPAs (35 percent) and the additional SPAs (65 percent) based on the relative proportion of field
interventions.  A  standard  conversion  factor  was  applied  to  domestic  prices  in  line  with  recent
ADB estimates.  The  opportunity  cost  of  labor  was  derived from applying  a  shadow  wage  rate
factor of 0.8 to unskilled labor, which was converted to border prices by applying the standard
conversion factor.24

99.
Direct and indirect benefits are included. The direct benefits are realized on-site, such as
the  value  of  incremental  output  of  commercial  logs  and  poles  and  of  limited  agricultural
production. The indirect benefits are limited to the enrichment of protection forests in the upland
agroecological  zone  and  include  the  loss  of  hydroelectric  generating  capacity  based  on  past
local data sets. Where appropriate, income foregone is included as a negative benefit to reflect
the  without  project  scenario.  Several  benefits  are  not  quantified  due  to  the  paucity  of  data.
These  include  the  value  of  additional  carbon  sequestration  and  the  intrinsic  value  of  habitat
saved from ongoing conversion to agricultural use. Carbon sequestration can be estimated but
there  is  little  indication of a  willingness  to  pay  for  the  carbon  sequestering  potential  within  Sri
Lanka. Habitat values have been estimated for lowland wet zone forests; however these are not
likely  to  reflect  the  average  willingness  to  pay  for  lesser-known  sites  in  Sri  Lanka.  Without  a
substantial research project there is inadequate data to assign such values. The project benefits
will  accrue  from  sustainable  forest  management  that  will  provide  logs,  poles,  and  agricultural
crops. Border prices  were used for  valuing  logs and  were  adjusted for  transport  and  handling
charges.

100.
The  estimated  economic  internal  rates  of  return  (IRR)  for  the  core  subprojects  range
from 13 percent for Badulla and Nuwara Eliya to 20 percent for Ratnapura. The variation reflects
the  differing  production  systems  and  the  high  proportion  of  rehabilitation  and  enrichment
planting in the Ratnapura SPA. Details are shown in Appendix 11.

2. 

Financial Analysis

Financial  viability  was  tested only for production  systems  that  require a  profit  incentive
101.
for the beneficiary to support the adoption in the project area. Four activities are analyzed, each
with the private sector as the primary beneficiary: (i) local communities convert the use of land
from shifting cultivation to diversified agroforestry; (ii) involving woodlots owned or managed by
local  community  members  who  have  little  or  knowledge  on  silviculture  or  marketing  of  trees;

                                               
24 A  shadow  wage  rate  of  0.8  has  been  used  following  ADB’s  Loan  1716-SRI:  Coastal Resource Management

Project, for $40 million, approved on 7 December 1999.

 26

(iii) the  intensification  of  agricultural  practice  in  encroached  land,  based  on  lowland  tea
production; and (iv) the establishment of private sector forest concession operations.

102.
The  characteristics  of  the  production  systems  and  the  financial  IRR  calculations  are
shown in Appendix 11. The financial IRRs of 13-16 percent reflect the sustainability of the forest
management regime to meet the return on labor necessary to demonstrate that participants can
afford  to  invest  their  labor.  The  analysis  is  based  on  partial  cost  recovery  through  labor
contributions from beneficiaries and the provision of free forestry materials.

3.

Risks

 
 103.
The  major  risks  to  the  Project  are  (i)  delays,  and  noncompliance  with  policy  and
institutional reforms needed for better sector performance, (ii) failure of potential beneficiaries to
actively participate, and (iii) inefficient coordination between relevant government agencies.

104. Specific  safeguards  against  these  risks  have  been  incorporated  in  the  Project  design.
For  (i),  some  reforms  may  not  be  easily  carried  out  due  to  the  lack  of  understanding  among
people and political resistance from vested interest groups. This risk will be minimized through
an effective awareness and extension campaign. The Project includes assistance to establish a
media unit and undertake an awareness and extension program to establish a constituency of
beneficiaries,  NGOs,  CBOs,  and  civil  society  to  demand  adherence  to  the  policy  and
institutional reforms. It was agreed that public awareness campaign and extension program will
be undertaken  within 6  months after  loan effectiveness.  Furthermore, frequent  policy dialogue
and  close  monitoring  of  the  time-  bound  policy  and  institutional  reforms  and  timely  corrective
action from ADB will minimize this risk. For (ii), the extension programs and financial incentives
will facilitate beneficiaries’ participation. NGOs and CBOs are expected to play an important role
in promoting the participatory approach to minimize the risk. For (iii), project implementation will
be  carried  out  through  several  coordination  mechanisms.  Through  close  consultation  among
relevant  agencies  the  NPIU  and  DCC  at  the  field  level  will  serve  as  effective  coordination
bodies.  MFE  is  experienced  with  coordinating  various  activities.  Relevant  agencies,  including
MFE  and  FD,  have  recognized  that  illegal  logging  and  the  high  demand  for  industrial  wood
contribute  to  forest  depletion  and  have  taken  strong  measures  to  avoid  overexploitation  by
commercial interests. This matter will be discussed during the coordination meetings.

B.

Environment

The  Project  is  designed  to  enhance  the  environmental  conditions  of  the  core  SPAs,25
105.
and  is  to  be  undertaken  through  participatory  and  bottom-up  planning  approaches.  The
environmental  impact  screening  has  not  identified  any  significant  adverse  environmental
impacts. Minor adverse impacts under the commercial forest management, which far outweigh
the benefits, can easily be mitigated.

106.
The  main  benefits  expected  from  the  protection  forestry  interventions  and  public
awareness  and  extension  services  in  the  wet  zone  are  (i)  biodiversity,  soil,  and  water
conservation in  southwest  Sri Lanka,  an area  with  an  unusually high  concentration of  species
and with exceptionally high levels of endemism and over 95 percent of the country’s threatened
plant  and  animal  species;  (ii)  global  importance  for  the  conservation  of  the  world’s  floristic
diversity  in  the  highly  threatened  area  of  southwest  Sri  Lanka;  (iii)  the  awareness  of
conservation  among  peripheral  communities  of  protection  and  conservation  forests  and  the
general public; and (iv) publication of information relevant to conservation and biodiversity.

                                               
25  Project interventions are expected to generate similar positive environmental benefits in the additional SPAs.

 27

107. Reforestation provides  a  range  of  environmental benefits  and  services.  Increasing  tree
cover  can  increase  soil  fertility  by  improving  moisture  retention,  soil  structure,  and  nutrient
content. Tree cover helps to reduce rapid runoff of rainwater, thereby regulating stream flow and
improving  water  quality  by  reducing  sediment  in  surface  waters.  Incorporating  trees  into
agricultural systems can improve crop yields by improving soil and the microclimate.

108. Commercial  plantation activities  provide  increased  revenue  to  the  Government,  private
sector  involvement  in  plantation  activities,  and  a  continuous  supply  of  wood  from  plantations.
Agroforestry  woodlot  activities  will  reduce  the  area  under  shifting  cultivation  and  provide
permanent  supplementary  income  to  farmers.  Improvements  to  existing  farmer  woodlots  will
increase  the  quality and quantity of  wood  coming to the  market.  The  project  interventions  will
improve the protection, conservation, and management of forests urgently needing protection by
reducing or halting the encroachments and illicit felling of timber. The Project will also increase
the awareness of conservation among peripheral communities and in the general public. If the
Project is not implemented, the degradation of resources in these forest reserves will continue.
The  proposed  restructuring  of  FD  will  allow  efficient  management  of  forest  resources  in  the
country, which will contribute to the protection of the environment.

109.
The  sustainable  management  of  dry  zone  forest  reserves  under  the  social  forestry
interventions  will  increase  the  benefit  flow  to  surrounding  communities.  Land  leased  for
agroforestry  woodlots  will  provide  continued  income  to  the  farmers  and  discourage  shifting
cultivation.  Improved  management  of  existing  woodlots  will  provide  incentives  for  continued
smallholder management.

C.

Impacts on Poverty

110.
The Project  will  benefit about  50,000  households  and  directly  generate about  6  million
person-days of work for the rural sector. It will have an impact on reducing poverty in the rural
area, where 35 percent of the population  live  under  the poverty  line.  The  Project  will  increase
employment  and  income  generation  opportunities  through  increasing  the  activities  within  the
forest  and  allied  sectors.  In  rural  communities,  livelihood  adjacent  to  forest  reserves  will  be
supported in order to stabilize land use and create greater tenurial certainty over land and trees.
In Anuradhapura, approximately 2,500 marginal and landless women and men will receive long-
term leases to FD land for agroforestry plots and farmer woodlots (2,500 ha). The provision of
supplemental  income  from  the  wood  portion  of  these  plots  helps  to  reduce  household
vulnerability  during  years  of  poor  rainfall.  About  2,500  farmers  with  woodlots  will  benefit  from
training  and  marketing  activities,  and  will  thus  increase  their  income.  An  annual  increase  of
household  income  is  estimated  at  SLRs1,000-2,000  ($14-27)  depending  on  the  agroforestry
model.

The forest  reserve buffer  zone development  intervention  will  be  implemented  in  critical
111.
communities  of  Ratnapura  wet  zone  district  to  provide  financial  training  and  alternatives  to
expanding  the  tea  garden  areas.  Assistance  for  savings  mobilization  and  access  to  existing
financial institutions is expected to help tea smallholders manage their finances for other income
generating  activities.  Additional  interventions  in  Ratnapura  include  rehabilitation  of  degraded
plantations  (1,250  ha)  and  enrichment and  management  of  protection  forests  (400  ha),  which
will have a long-term impact on increasing income and reducing poverty.

112.  A  total  of  about  50,000  beneficiary  household  will  directly  benefit  from  the  Project
through  participation  in  the  reforestation  activities.  Of  the  households  in  core  SPAs,  40-65
percent  are  below  the  poverty  line  and  will  benefit  from  improved  productive  activities  in
forestlands, where they will have greater security of tenure, and from employment opportunities
generated by the Project. By deregulating the sector operations and adopting multistakeholder

 28

and  community-based  resource  development  and  management,  the  Project  will  help  the
Government improve the governance of the sector  by  making all  parties  involved  in  the forest
sector  more  accountable.  Furthermore, 
implementation
arrangements  will  ensure  transparency.  More  importantly,  institutionalization  of  participatory
forestry  management  will  help  make  benefit-sharing from forest  resources  more  accessible  to
the local poor and improve the socioeconomic status of the local communities. This will enable
them  to  maximize  their  chances  for  being  able  to  access  and  influence  the  development
programs and projects that can enhance their livelihoods.

the  operating  procedures  and 

VI.

ASSURANCES

A. 

Specific Assurances

113.  The specific assurances are as follows:

(i)

(ii) 

MFE  and  FD,  in  consultation  with  the  Survey  Department  of  the  Ministry  of
Agriculture  and  Lands,  will  prepare  a  time-bound  operational  plan  to  survey,
delineate,  demarcate,  map,  and  redraw  forest  boundaries  using  agreed  upon
ecological  criteria,  and  the  MFE  and  FD  will  ensure  that  a  management  unit  that
contains similar prescriptions is not split as a result of the demarcation.

During  2001,  2002,  and  2003,  STC  will  have  guaranteed  access  to  state  forest
plantations  with  annual  harvesting  rights  over  1,200  ha  (the  level  earmarked  for
2000) provided the area harvested by STC during 2001, equals or exceeds 1,200 ha
allocation. If STC is unable to meet the 2001 harvesting target, the annual allocation
for 2002 and 2003 will be limited to  the  maximum  area  that  STC harvested during
2001. Free and open competitive bidding for the remaining area (not less than 600
ha in 2002 and 2003) that is available for harvesting under the existing management
plans or the IFRMPs, is to be made available to STC and the private sector equally,
in  accordance  with  open and  competitive  bidding  procedures.  At  the  end  of  2003,
STC’s  special  allocation  of  harvesting  rights  will  be  reviewed  by  an  independent
committee  comprising  a  multidisciplinary  team  of  experts  selected  in  consultation
with ADB, with the objective of enhancing private sector participation.

(iii) 

The  Borrower  will  issue  long-term  lease/management-rights  to  all  participating
farmers in the woodlots program, and ensure that (a) the CF has delegated power to
issue  leases  over  state  land;  (b)  until  the  delegation  is  formalized,  the  Land
Commissioner will facilitate the leasing process; and (c) for private sector leasehold
management  of  state  forest  plantations  rules  and  procedures  in  line  with  the
National Forestry Policy are adopted and formalized.

(iv)  MFE  will  (a)  undertake  a  thorough  public  awareness  campaign  for  forestry
management  and  deregulation;  (b)  deregulate  nationally, 
timber  and  wood
harvesting  and  transport  for  agreed  species  found  on  private  lands,  in  the  agreed
phased manner, with an annual review conducted jointly; (c) eliminate excess stock
examinations of all private wood enterprises by the end of 2001; and (d) conduct a
review  by  end  of  2003 for  deregulation  of  jak timber harvesting  and  transport  with
the Ministry of Agriculture and Lands.

(v) 

By  31  December  2001,  the  Borrower  will  submit  to  Parliament,  a  bill  to  amend  or
replace  the  Forest  Ordinance  and  will  approve  associated  regulations  to  bring  the
legislative  framework  in  line  with  the  imperatives  and  strategies  enunciated  in  the
National Forest Policy.

 B.

Conditions of Loan Effectiveness

29

114.  As  conditions  of  effectiveness  of  the  Loan  Agreement,  the  Government  will  have  (i)
established (a) DPIUs in each core subproject division, (b) a PSC at the national level, and (c) a
DCC within FD; (ii) appointed the required staff to the NPIU and assigned the CF for operations
and support staff; and (iii) prepared proforma agreements for implementing partners.

VII.

 RECOMMENDATION

115.
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  loan  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of

Forest Resources Management Sector Project, with a term of 32 years, including a grace period
of  8  years  and  with  an  interest  charge  at  the  rate  of  1  percent  per  annum  during  the  grace
period  and  1.5  percent  per  annum  thereafter,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set forth  in  the  draft  Loan  Agreement  presented  to  the
Board.

FOREST SECTOR DEVELOPMENT—LESSONS LEARNED

A. 

Asian Development Bank (ADB) Projects in Sri Lanka

1. 

Community Forestry Project

The Community Forestry Project,1 with $10.0 million financed by ADB, was completed in
1.
1991.  This  project  aimed  at  supplying  Sri  Lanka  with  needed  fuelwood  and  timber  from
conventional reforestation in block plantations and a small social forestry component designed
to  pursue  tree  cultivation  through  community  involvement.  The  Country  Synthesis  of
Postevaluation in Sri Lanka2 rated the project as generally successful. The report concluded that
the  project  had  made  positive  ecological  impacts,  including  soil  conservation,  stabilization  of
hydrological systems, and creation of wind shelters.

2.
The project concept was sound, with a lower risk plantation component being combined
with  a  more  innovative  community  forestry  component.  However,  community  participation  in
reforestation can only be fully achieved if the community is involved throughout the project cycle
including  the  planning  and  monitoring  phase.  Tree  planting  can  conflict  with  peak  agricultural
activities,  which  should  be  considered  when  scheduling  implementation  and  determining
compensation.  Individual  farm  households  need  immediate  compensation,  such  as  food  for
work, to enable them to undertake tree cultivation, particularly during peak season for work on
agricultural  crops.  To  assure  the  needed  level  and  means  of  community  participation  in  a
reforestation project, appropriate disciplinary expertise must be employed during the preparation
of  the feasibility  study and  appraisal.  Participating  families  need  secure  rights  and  benefits  to
harvest final products with appropriate lease/management agreement.

2.

Participatory Forestry Project

The  ongoing  Participatory  Forestry  Project3  commenced  in  1993  and  was  originally
3.
scheduled  for  completion  in  1999.  The  project  may  be  extended  into  2000.  The  project  is
cofinanced  by  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID),  which  has
provided 30,000 tons of wheat as food aid. The food aid component is to provide farmers with
as  compensation  for  time  spent  on  tree  planting  and  maintenance  activities.  The  main
objectives of the project are to increase villagers’ incomes through participation in reforestation,
to increase tree planting, and to strengthen the institutional  capacity  of  the  Forest  Department
(FD). This project built upon the lessons learned from the Community Forestry Project.

4.
ADB’s midterm review in 1996 confirmed that the project had achieved 70 percent of its
planting target. By the end of project implementation, the planted area is expected to reach 150
percent of the 15,000 hectares target.

5.
Useful  lessons  can  be  derived  from  the  project  implementation.  For  example,  some
leases do not extend until the harvest age of trees being grown, and most leases are signed by
men, although women play a critical role in woodlot establishment and maintenance. While FD
has demonstrated strong  skills  in  meeting  reforestation  targets  through  the  use  of  community
labor,  the  gradual  shift  of  allowing  farmers  greater  decision-making  in  woodlot  designs  and

longer-term  rights over  land  and  products  should  be  encouraged.  Successful  and  sustainable
social  forestry  programs  will  depend  on  the  strengthening  of  community  groups  and  farmer
organizations to develop their own methods for incorporating trees into farming systems.

3.

Upper Watershed Management Project

The  ongoing  Upper  Watershed  Management  Project4  commenced  in  1998  to  (i)
6.
rehabilitate, sustainably manage, and protect critical watersheds; (ii) improve incomes of project
beneficiaries;  and  (iii)  strengthen  the  capacity  of  watershed  management  agencies,  including
FD. The project is currently being implemented and is performing satisfactorily.

B.

Other External Assistance to the Forestry Sector in Sri Lanka

1. 

Forest Resources Development Project

7.
The World Bank and the Finnish International Development Agency (FINNIDA) invested
$11.4  million  between  1983  and  1986  for  the  Forest  Resources  Development  Project.  The
objectives  were  to  (i)  prepare  a  forest  master  plan  (FMP),  (ii)  conduct  a  forest  inventory  and
establish  a  data  base,  and  (iii)  strengthen  FD’s  institutional  capacity.  Although  the  FMP  was
adopted  in  1990,  it  was  criticized  for  not  being  based  on  adequate  consultation  with
stakeholders, lacking in conservation orientation, and being too concerned with the production
aspects  of  forestry.  However,  the  FMP  did  provide  a  valuable  data  and  technical  base  to
prepare subsequent planning in the forestry and forest industries sector. This led to planning of
the Forestry Sector Development Project, described next.

2. 

Forestry Sector Development Project

8.
The World Bank, FINNIDA, the United Kingdom’s Overseas Development Administration
(ODA),  and  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP)  invested  $46.4  million
between 1991 and 1996 to help the Government improve the performance of the forest sector in
line  with  Sri  Lanka’s  economic,  social,  and  environmental  requirements  by  implementing  five
years (990-1994) of the FMP. The project objectives were to (i) achieve intensive management
of  plantations  and  natural  forests,  (ii)  establish  an  environmental  management  system,  (iii)
expand the forest resource base by establishing new plantations, (iv) augment professional and
technical  education  and  training  of  farmers,  and  (v)  strengthen  FD’s  institutional  base.  The
project  developed  a  forest  sector  master  plan  that  provides  a  long-term  sector  development
framework from 1995 to 2020,  taking  into  account  lessons  learned  from  the  FMP  and  putting
more emphasis on participatory approaches in forestry resource management.

9.
The  implementation  completion  report  summarized  the  lessons  learned  as  follows:  (i)
plantation sites should be clearly identified in order to ensure land is available for plantations; (ii)
the  performance  of  FD  was  not  satisfactory,  in  part  due  to  understaffing,  outdated  financial
regulations,  and  over-centralized  decision-making;  (iii)  realistic  interventions  should  be
envisaged  (including  more  private  sector  participation)  as  a  result  of  institutional  capacity
analysis; and (iv) any sector reform needs to overcome possible strong resistance from vested
interest groups.

The  World  Bank  expressed  concern  at  the  lack  of  progress  in  addressing  important
10.
policy  issues  such  as  review  of  stumpage  charges  and  restructuring  of  the  State  Timber
                                               
4 

Loan 1545-SRI: Upper Watershed Management Project, for $16.6 million, approved on 24 September 1997.

 42

Appendix 3, page 3

Corporation (STC). It was recognized that these issues needed to be addressed in future as an
integral  part  of  any  investment  projects  in  the  forestry  sector,  to  allow  them  to  yield  positive
results.

C.

Lessons Learned and their Incorporation in the Project

1.

Deregulation of Forest Related Activities

Many  forest-related  activities,  including  transportation  of  timbers  and  harvesting  of
11.
considerable  numbers  of  species  grown  on  private  land,  are  currently  subject  to  strict
regulations.  Deregulation  should  be  promoted  to  enable  the  field-level  FD  staff  to  be  more
actively involved in forest resource management activities with local communities, rather than in
legal enforcement activities.

12.
The Government agreed that regulation of timber and wood felling would be phased out
with specified time-bound targets. The targets specify the names and numbers of species that
will  be  exempt  from  permits  nationwide  at  the  agreed  time.  In  year  three,  the  jak  felling  and
transport will be deregulated and the findings of the review used to guide the decision making
about possible deregulation of felling jackfruit trees. The Project, at the same time, will support
the development of media capacity and campaigns for public awareness  about  the  benefits of
deregulation and other policy reforms.

2.

Delineation and Demarcation of the State Forests

Ambiguousness  in  the  boundaries  of  state  forests  has  encouraged  encroachment  and
13.
illicit harvesting. Clear delineation and demarcation of the forests and appropriate legislation is
imperative  for  more  efficient  and  effective  enforcement  forest  boundaries  and  to  protect  the
remaining  natural  forest.  This  is  also  a  prerequisite  for  planning  and  implementing  integrated
forest resources management.

14.
A  bill  will  be  introduced  in  the  Parliament  to  amend  or  replace  the  1907  Forest
Ordinance  and  approve  associated  regulations  with  provisions  for  classification  forests  under
FD’s  jurisdiction.  The  Project  will  support  the  demarcation  of  legal  boundaries  on  the  ground
through  the  surveying  and demarcation  of  the  forest  in  close  consultation  and  participation  of
local  communities.  A  total  of  17,500  km  of  surveying  and  demarcation  will  be  completed  to
establish  a  permanent  forest  area  and  facilitate  integrated  ecosystems  based  forest  resource
management planning and implementation.

3.

Institutional Reforms

To facilitate  integrated forest  resource  management  at  regional  level,  FD’s  institutional
15.
capacity should be enhanced through organizational restructuring including decentralization and
devolution  of  authority  and  redeployment  of  field  level  staff.  The  Government  agreed  to
establish four regional Conservators of Forest (CFs), devolve the authority to regional CFs, and
to divisional, range, and beat forest officers, and rationalize the head office structure in line with
the  decentralization.  Range  and  beat  boundaries  will  be  redrawn  to  ensure  appropriate  and
effective integrated forest resource management.

 43

Appendix 3, page 4

4.

Monopoly of the State Timber Corporation (STC)

16.
Distortion and inefficiency of markets results from STC’s de facto monopoly. STC enjoys
a monopoly on harvesting and sale of wood from state natural forests and plantations. Because
STC  pays  a  very  low  stumpage  fee,  STC  has  not  had  to  become  commercially  oriented  and
institutionally  efficient.  Efforts  to  establish  a  more  fair,  competitive,  and  efficient  market
environment are of particular importance.

The  Government  will  promote  private  sector  participation  in  all  forestry  operations,
17.
including harvesting, reforestation, and silviculture of state-owned plantations through an  open
competitive bidding process. To enable STC to adjust to a competitive environment, the annual
minimum  area  for  harvesting  will  be  allocated  to  STC  for  the  next  three  years.  At  the  end  of
Project year three, the protection of STC will be independently reviewed.

5.

Rights for Land Use

Beneficiaries  of  existing  social  forestry  have  expressed  concerns  about  their  rights  to
18.
land-use  because  the  lease  and  management  agreements  are  not  extended  until  the  trees
reach a harvestable age; and required periodical renewal of targets. New legislative framework
will  be  introduced  to  allow  appropriate  leasing/management  contract  arrangements  that
authorize FD to enter into partnerships with smallholders and private sector firms for longer term
management  agreements  for  tree  farms,  woodlots,  and  plantations.  These  contracts  will  be
cosigned by both spouses (if both are living).

6.

Public Awareness

19.
Public  awareness  is  key  for  promoting  participation  in  forest  resource  management
activities  and  for  the  success  of  policy  and  institutional  reforms,  which  may  attract  resistance
from  vested  interest  groups.  The  Project  will  support  the  development  of  media  capacity  and
media  campaigns  for  public  awareness  about  the  benefits  of  deregulation  and  other  policy
reforms  by  assisting  the  establishment  of  a  media  center  within  the  Ministry  of  Forestry  and
Environment.

D.

ADB's Forestry Sector Projects in Other Countries

1. 

Bangladesh5

20.
In Bangladesh, severe population pressure has resulted in continued deforestation and
degradation of the country's remaining forestry resources. Bangladesh has received substantial
external  assistance  for  forestry  since  1980.  This  includes  two  ADB  projects  (Community
Forestry Project in 1981 and Upazila [Thana] Afforestation and Nursery Development Project in
1989)6,  both  of  which  aimed  at  promoting  people-oriented  forest  development.  Given  the
continued  resource  degradation  and  deficits  faced  by  country,  the  Government,  with  ADB
assistance,  formulated  the  Forestry  Sector  Mater  Plan  (FSMP),  which  provides  an  overall
strategy for forest  sector development  through  policy and  institutional  reforms  and  investment
plans for over 20 years, incorporating a people-oriented forest resource management approach.

Loan 1486-BAN: Forestry Sector Project, for $50 million, approved on 21 November 1996.

                                               
5

1989.

21.
ADB  approved  the  Forestry  Sector  Project  in  1996.  It  is  the  first  major  intervention  to
promote forest  resource  management  activities  in  line  with  the  FSMP.  The  Project  adopted  a
sector approach because of the importance of institutionalizing sustainable forest management
through local community participation, accompanied by institutional capacity building and policy
reforms. The sector approach was justified by the need to enhance the institutional capacities of
FD, executing agency of the Project. The scope of the Project includes (i) institutionalization of
community participation in forest management, thereby increasing overall wood production and
promoting  forest  conservation,  and  (ii)  enhancement  of  capacity  of  FD  and  nongovernment
organizations (NGOs).

2. 

Pakistan7

22.
The capacity of Pakistan’s forest sector to meet the country's wood demand was being
severely reduced by the rapid depletion of forests, largely due to the country's rapid population
growth  (3  percent  a  year).  The  Government  had  implemented  a  number  of  externally  funded
projects,  but  they  were  only  partly  successful  in  mitigating  the  high  rate  of  depletion  of  the
forestry  resources.  With  the  aim  of  developing  long-term  solution  to  the  problem,  the
Government  in  1992  prepared  an  FSMP  with  ADB's  assistance.  The  FSMP  describes  a
comprehensive forest sector development strategy.

23.
ADB approved  the  Forestry  Sector  Project  in 1995 as a  first  major  effort  to  implement
Pakistan’s FSMP. The Project was formulated using a sector approach to expand the models of
beneficiary in designing, planning, and implementing project-related  activities,  which  had been
tested under past projects. This approach was to develop an institutional environment and apply
these  models  consistently  in  all  forestry  activities  throughout  the  targeted  provinces,  thus
ensuring  the  sustainability  of  forestry  resources.  Community-based  organizations  were
organized  and  involved  in  the  design  and  execution  of  the  integrated  resource  management
plans, including participatory village lands-use planning within the subprojects.

24.
Further  enhancement  of  institutional  capacity  of  the  Department  of  Forests,  Fisheries,
and Wildlife (DFFW), the executing agency of the Project, was an important component of the
Project;  while  DFFW  had  demonstrated  its  capability  to  implement  forest  projects,  several
activities were identified to make DFFW to be better prepared to meet the requirements of social
forestry with its decentralized and community-oriented mandate. Legal reform was also required
in  the  context  of  the  Project  so  that  the  legal  framework  for  the  forestry  sector  would  be
consistent  with  the  Government's  policy,  and  complement  and  provide  an  impetus  to  the  full
development of social forestry.

Loan 1403-PAK: Forestry Sector Project, for $42.6 million, approved on 9 November 1995.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES

1.
The consulting services will be provided by an international consulting firm in association
with  domestic  consulting  firms,  engaged  in  accordance  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  The  consulting  firm  will  ensure  that  the  Forest
Department (FD) receives the required support in accordance with a predetermined mobilization
schedule. The consultants will be engaged under a single contract, comprising the  services of
the international and domestic consultants acting as one team of experts.

2.
A  total  of  230  person-months  of  consulting  services  is  required  including  153  person-
months of domestic and 77 person-months of international consultant inputs. International input
will be provided as follows: (i) integrated forest management planner (for 27 person-months); (ii)
forest  biometrics  and  management  specialist  (14),  (iii)  training  specialist  (12),  (iv)  production
forestry  specialist  (9),  (v)  participatory  social  forestry  specialist  (6),  (vi)  public  awareness  and
extension specialist (3), and (vii) commercial forest concessionaire specialist (6). Domestic input
will  be  as  follows:  (i)  public  awareness  and  extension  specialist  (for  36  person-months),  (ii)
participatory forestry specialist (21), (iii) institutional strengthening specialist (18), (iv) mapping,
geographic  information  systems  (GIS)  and  management  information  systems  (MIS)  database
specialist  (24),  (v)  forest  seed  and  stand  improvement  specialist  (24),  (vi)  tree  improvement
specialist  (12),  (vii)  ecosystem  management  specialist  (6),  (viii)  biodiversity  MIS  specialist  (4),
and (ix) impact monitoring and evaluation specialist (8).

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION

SRI: FOREST RESOURCES MANAGEMENT SECTOR PROJECT

A.

Introduction

1.
This report presents the summary initial environmental examination of activities proposed
under the Forest Resource Management Project (the Project). The report is based on information
gathered  during  the  feasibility  study,  review  of  reports  available  in  the  core  subproject  areas
(SPAs), and data collected by the project preparation technical assistance team. The three core
SPAs,  corresponding  to  the  existing  forest  divisions,  were  selected  to  represent  the  various
climatic  and  ecological  conditions.  This  report  follows  the  initial  environment  examination
procedures developed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and listed in ADB’s Environmental
Guidelines for Selected Agriculture  and  Natural Resources Development Projects,  1991  and
Environmental Assessment Requirements and Environmental Review, 1993.

B.

Description of the Project

in 

2.
Selected  core  SPAs  are  in  the  north  central  dry  zone,  the  southwest  and  center  of  the
lowland wet zone, and the up-country wet and intermediate zones. The objectives of the proposed
Project  are  to  (i)  assist  the  Ministry  of  Forestry  and  Environment    (MFE)  and  the  Forest
Department  (FD) 
their  efforts  at  sustainable  development,  effective  protection,  and
decentralized management of forest resources by facilitating establishment of a permanent forest
and  instituting  appropriate  ecosystems-based  integrated  resource  management,  including
participatory  rehabilitation  and  management  of  degraded  natural  forests  and  plantations;  (ii)
provide  support  to  people-oriented  forestry  and  private  sector  participation  in  forest  resource
development and management; and  (iii)  strengthen the capacity of  MFE  and  FD  as  well  as  the
community-based organizations, and enhance their institutional effectiveness.

3.
To  achieve  the  objectives,  the  Project  will  support  the  implementation  of  the  Five-Year
Implementation  Plan  in  17  of  the  19  forest  divisions.1  Activities  to  be  supported  include  the
Forestry  Sector  Master  Plan  and  National  Forest  Policy  that  are  directly  linked  to  the  project
objectives of integrated ecosystem-based forest resource management.

4.
The Project follows a sector approach. The selected SPAs conform to the existing forest
divisions,  with  some  of  the  divisions  being  combined  because  of  their  similar  agro-ecological
features. Other criteria for constituting the SPAs include (i) size, (ii) security, (iii) resource base,
(iv) willingness of the communities to participate, (v) population pressure, and (vi) environmental
priority.  Three  core  SPAs  (Anuradhapura  Division,  Badulla  and  Nuwara  Eliya  divisions
[combined],  and  Ratnapura  Division),  were  selected  for  a  detailed  assessment  during  the
feasibility  study  as  they  appropriately  represent  the  nature  and  distribution  of  forests  in  the
country and the entire range of proposed interventions. The additional seven SPAs include the
remaining secure 13 forest divisions and exclude divisions that are otherwise inaccessible or do
not conform to the agreed selection criteria.

5. 
The  identified  activities  for  each  SPA  include  (i)  agroforestry  woodlots,  (ii)  improved
management  of  existing  woodlots,  (iii)  improved  management  of  commercial  forests,  (iv)
rehabilitation and management of degraded plantations, (v) private sector management of state

C.

Description of the Environment

The project activities  will be carried  out  in  three  core  SPAs  representing  all  agroclimatic
7.
zones of the country: Anuradhapura (dry zone); Badulla and Nuwara Eliya (wet and intermediate
zones), and Ratnapura (wet zone).

1.

Physical Resources

a.

Topography

Most of the forests in the Ratnapura core SPA have a parallel ridge and valley topography
8.
with an east-west trend. The general elevation of the division ranges from 30 to 2,135 meters (m)
above mean sea level. In Badulla-Nuwara Eliya SPA, elevation varies from about 900 to 2,400 m
and the SPA has a variety of complex of landform features  such  as  mountain  ranges, plateaus,
plains,  valleys,  and  slopes.  Topographically,  Anuradhapura  core  SPA  belongs  to  the  lowest
peneplain with gently undulating lands. The average elevation of the area is 178 m.

b.

Geology and Soil

9.
Ratnapura SPA has a highland series of Precambrian rocks that are widely distributed in
the northern part of the division. The southern part has two important rock types: a southwestern
group of meta sediments and a highland group of khondalites and charnokites. The predominant
soil type in Ratnapura division  is  "red-yellow podsols  (ultisols).  This  soil type  is found  in steeply
dissected,  hilly,  and  rolling  terrain  and  is  developed  on  a  wide  variety  of  parent  materials.  In
mountainous areas, red-yellow podsolic soils and mountain regosols are found.

Badulla-Nuwara  Eliya  SPA  belongs  to  the  highland  series  of  the  Precambrian  complex.
10.
The major rock types are quartzites, marble, and granites. The dominant types of soil include red-
yellow podsols, reddish-brown latosols, and immature brown loams and regosols. The red-yellow
podsolic soils are  widely  distributed throughout  Nuwara Eliya.  Anuradhapura division belongs to
the highland  series of Sri Lanka, and  its underlying  rocks are  charnokite, quartzite, and  marble.
The soil in the dry zone is classified as an alfisol, which broadly corresponds to the reddish-brown
earths.  Chemically, this  soil  type is  considered moderately  rich soil but  poor  in  phosphorus  and
nitrogen.

 58

Appendix 9, page 3

c.

Climate

11.
Ratnapura SPA  receives between 3,810 and 5,080 millimeters (mm) of  rainfall  annually,
averaging  more  than  3,000  mm,  and  has  no  dry  season.  The  highest  rainfall  and  the  lowest
temperature  are  recorded  in  Nuwara  Eliya.  Watawala  receives  the  highest  annual  rainfall,
exceeding  5,588  mm.  Nuwara  Eliya  experiences  the  lowest  monthly  average  temperature  of
about 7.2ºC, and the temperature occasionally falls below freezing. The average annual rainfall in
Badulla  is  around  2,000  mm.  The  average  annual  temperature  of  the  division  varies  between
20.0ºC and 25.0ºC depending on the altitude. Anuradhapura’s dry zone has an annual rainfall of
1,329 mm and mean annual temperature of 27.3ºC.

2.

Ecological Resources

a.

Forest Cover

12.
The latest forest inventory (1992) showed dense natural forest cover in 24 percent of Sri
Lanka’s  land  area,  and  7  percent  of  the  land  covered  with  sparse,  open  forests.  The  FD  and
Department of Wildlife Conservation control the natural forests.

13.
Nearly  14  percent  of  Sri  Lanka’s  land  area  is  protected  area.  All  categories  of  reserves
managed by the Department of Wildlife Conservation are regarded as protected areas. The man
and biosphere reserves, protection and conservation forests (30), Sinharaja World Heritage Site,
and  Knuckles  and  Kanneliya-Dediyagala-Nakiyadeniya  forest  reserves  managed  by  FD  are
considered to be protected areas.

14.
Forest  resources  in  Ratnapura  SPA  include  a  large  number  of  high-value  forest
reserves—49,038 hectares (ha) of proposed forest reserves and forest reserves. Badulla-Nuwara
Eliya SPA has the smallest area of natural forests (38,392 ha of proposed and existing reserves)
of the three core SPAs, and Anuradhapura, the largest (180,776 ha). However, the forest reserve
area in the north and eastern portion of the division is not accessible at this time due to terrorist
activities.

b.

Forest Formations

15.
Vegetation  in  Ratnapura  SPA  can  be  classified  as  lowland  rain  forest,  submontane  and
upper  montane  rain  forest,  wet  patana  grassland,  and  tree  savanna.  The  dominant  vegetation
type is lowland rain forest. The lowland wet zone forests in Ratnapura SPA are classified as Wet
Evergreen Forest Climax, Wet Tropical Evergreen Forest, Toona-Dipterocarpus-Mesua series.

16.
The  vegetation  of  the  submontane  area  in  Ratnapura  is  described  as  the  Toona-
Calophyllum-Syzygium  series.  The  forests  of  this  series  are  shorter  than  lowland  evergreen
forests; lack huge large buttressing roots; and have a large number of species descending from
upper altitudes, in particular the family Lauraceae.

Natural  vegetation  in Badulla-Nuwara  Eliya SPA  includes  submontane  rain  forest,  upper
17.
montane rain forest, tree savanna, and dry patana grassland. The vegetation of the submontane
forest  is described as the Toona-Calophyllum-Syzygium series. Physiognomically, the forests of
this series are shorter than the lowland evergreen forests; lack large buttressing roots; and have a
large number of species descending from upper altitudes, in particular the family Lauraceae. The
upper montane rain forests in the core SPA replace the lower montane rain forests above 1,500
m.  The upper  montane rain forests are  rich  in  epiphytes, orchids,  mosses,  and  filmy  ferns.  The
trees are stunted, with umbrella-shaped crowns and twisted branches. The forest is single-storied.

 59

Appendix 9, page 4

Understory vegetation is sparse due to lack of sunlight, which cannot penetrate through the dense
canopy.

18.
Natural  vegetation  in  Anuradhapura  core  SPA  includes  dry-mixed  evergreen  forest
(synonyms:  monsoon  forest,  seasonal  forest,  and  moist  deciduous  forest);  scrublands;  riverine
forest; villu grassland;  and tree-savanna.  The dominant forest  is dry-mixed evergreen of shorter
stature  and  with  less  biomass  than  lowland  rain  forest.  It  is  also  deciduous  to  a  considerable
degree.  Dry  mixed  evergreen  is  the  most  widespread  forest  formation  in  Sri  Lanka  and  is  very
characteristic of the lowland dry zone below 600 m.

c.

Biodiversity

The southwestern part of Sri Lanka (Galle, Kalutara, Matara, and Ratnapura) is one of the
19.
18 “hot spots” of the world because of the high number of endemic plant species. Among the flora
(3,600 flowering plants), as much as 23 percent of plant species are endemic to Sri Lanka, and 94
percent  of  the  endemics  are  confined  to  the  forests  in  low  and  upcountry  wet  zones.  Eighteen
percent of the ferns and 16 percent of the terrestrial vertebrates are endemic to the country, and
most of them are contained in natural forests of the wet zone. Closed canopy natural forest covers
around 10 percent of the wet zone land area and occurs in blocks scattered throughout the area.
Sri Lanka has 426 threatened flowering plants.  The 1997  National  Conservation  Review  survey
recorded 216 species of threatened flowering plants in the wet zone forests.

20.
The fauna exhibits a similar pattern of endemicity and distribution. The number of species
and the percentage of endemic species in some faunal groups are as follows: fish, 59 (of which 27
percent  are  endemic);  amphibians,  37  (51  percent);  reptiles,  139  (50  percent);  birds,  237  (8
percent);  and  mammals,  85  (14  percent).  The  vast  majority  of  endemic  species,  particularly
among fish, amphibians, and reptiles, are confined to the wet zone forests.

3.

Human and Economic Development

21.
According  to the demographic  survey of Sri Lanka  in 1994,  the  population  in  Ratnapura
Division was 917,349. The  rate of population growth in  Ratnapura  was estimated  to be about 1
percent  annually  from  1990  to  1994.  In  Anuradhapura,  the  total  population  in  1994  is  676,197.
Farmers in the dry zone have few economic alternatives to farming. Most households engage in
shifting cultivation on state land, which supplies about 30 percent of household income. Women
and children provide most of the labor for cultivation while men attend to rice paddies, either their
own or as  wage  laborers.  Landless  households  (those  with  only  sufficient  land  for  a  home  and
small  garden,  generally  less  than  0.1  ha)  are  potential  participants  in  smallholder  forest
management in the dry zone.

Anuradhapura  has  the  lowest  average  household  income  in  Sri  Lanka  (SLRs2,600  per
22.
household versus SLRs3,540 nationwide). In recent surveys (1997), 45 percent of children under
the age of five were malnourished, with 26 percent stunted. Because of the displacement by the
ethnic  conflict  in  the  north  and  east  of  the  country  and  dependence  on  farming  in  an  area  of
seasonal and varied rainfall, the populations are vulnerable to starvation and malnutrition.

23.
The population of Badulla and Nuwara Eliya is 749,549 and 671,344, respectively, based
on the 1994 demographic survey. Of the population, 56 percent  live  in  the  rural  villages and 38
percent on the estate plantations. The Tamils, who live mostly on the estate plantations in Nuwara
Eliya, comprise 44 percent of the population. Outside the estate plantations, the great majority of
the population are Sinhalese.

 60

Appendix 9, page 5

The  highland  areas  dominated  by  the  tea  estates  are  populated  by  Indian  Tamil  estate
24.
workers. The primary earners (with low wages) in the family are women who are employed as tea
pickers from 10 to 12  months a year.   Men are barely  able to find  work for three months in the
year.  As  an  alternative,  they  turn  to  encroachment  on  state  lands  for  vegetable  and  potato
production.

25.
The middle hill areas are predominately occupied by Sinhalese. Men are the primary wage
earners in agriculture and marketing.  Women tend home gardens, process saleable foods, and
engage in handicrafts. The 1990/1991 Household Income and Expenditure Survey in Badulla and
Nuwara Eliya shows earnings are 80 to 84 percent less than the national average.2 The incidence
of poverty was 36.8 percent in Badulla and 22.6 percent in Nuwara Eliya. Nationally, the average
is 30.4 percent.

4.

Quality of Life Values

26.
The  percentage  of  poverty  is  highest  in  the  rural  areas  (35  percent),  and  lowest  in  the
urban areas (18 percent). Malnutrition is widespread, especially among children and mothers. The
1993  and  1994  Sri  Lanka  Food  Balance  Sheets  show  low  average  availability  of  calories  per
capita  from  all  food  sources  against  a  recommended  minimum  of  2,100  calories  per  day.  The
infant mortality rate (up to age one) is 16 per thousand births. Of the 17 divisions where project
activities  are  being  carried  out,  6  are  considered  educationally  disadvantaged  divisions:3
Anuradhapura, Badulla and Nuwara Eliya, Hambantota, Monaragala, and Polonnaruwa.

D.

Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures

1.

Environmental Benefits and Mitigation Measures

a.

Environmental Impacts due to Project Location

27.
The Project  will  support the  survey  and  demarcation  of  permanent  forest  estates,  which
includes  surveying  the  boundaries  of  forest  reserves,  proposed  forest  reserves,  and  FD
plantations.  The  establishment  of  forest  reserve  boundaries  using  a  participatory  approach  will
create awareness of the importance of reserves and discourage further encroachments. This will
improve the biodiversity and soil and water conservation in all protection and conservation forests
identified by  National Conservation  Review  in the  wet  zone.  Management  of  the  protection  and
conservation forests will restrict encroachment for tea cultivation. Development of buffer zones in
protection and conservation forests and other forest reserves will benefit communities with limited
access to forests.

28.
Selection of land for farmer woodlots in the dry zone may cause  land-use  conflicts  if not
done through a participatory process. The area of land for grazing and food production could be
reduced.  The  development  of  agroforestry  and  plantations  may  cause  significant  social  and
environmental  impacts  if the  locations are not properly  selected.  The  use  of  FD  land  for  farmer
woodlots under the participatory forestry program will raise the issue of short- or long-term tenure
agreements  and  usufruct  rights.  Effective  participation  of  people  depends  on  their  rights  to  the
planted trees and tenure for at least one rotation. The commercial plantation management activity
will also have a positive impact on the environment. Proper care, however, will be needed in the
selection of sites with high productive potential and accessibility.

Potential Environmental Impacts due to Harvesting
and Reforestation

30.
The  establishment  of  large  commercial  plantations  may  cause  adverse  environmental
impacts during  site  preparation.  The  impacts may  include  accelerated  erosion,  disruption  of  the
hydrologic cycle, compaction of soil, loss of nutrients, and a decline in soil fertility. Many of these
impacts can be short-term until the vegetation cover is reestablished by replanting. The severity of
the impacts depends in large part on site conditions prior to planting, site preparation techniques,
species  to  be  planted,  treatments  during  rotation,  length  of  rotation,  and  harvesting  methods.
Reforestation  in dry areas  can deplete soil  moisture and lower  the  water  table. Soil  compaction
and  damage  can  occur  during  the  harvest  season  and  site  preparation.  Erosion  can  occur  in
plantations  with  incomplete  canopy  closure  or  limited  undergrowth.  Accumulation  of  leaf  litter
under plantations increases the risk of fire and decreases  rainwater  infiltration.  In  monocultures,
tree leaf litter may change the chemical and biological characteristics of the soil.

c.

Potential Environmental Impacts Associated with Project Design

31.
Dry  zone  reserves  under  the  Project  will  be  managed  through  participatory  land-use
planning  in  communities  within  and  surrounding  the  reserve.  The  lands  will  be  identified  for
multiple uses such as forest protection, grazing, and agroforestry woodlots (AFWs). Priority will be
given to individuals and communities within or in the periphery of the six reserves. AFW models
will need to be properly established to suit selected sites  in the dry zone  and  fulfill  the  farmers’
needs to avoid potential adverse environmental impacts. Evaluation of existing AFW models and
design  and  testing  of  new  models  in  the  dry  zone  can  provide  lessons  on  how  to  minimize
potential  adverse  impacts.  At  present,  people  collect  poles  and  fuelwood  from  abandoned
swiddens, degraded forests, and scrublands. It may be important to survey the demand for poles
and fuelwood before establishing plots in an area.

d.

Potential Environmental Impacts from Construction

The civil works under this Project will include (i) the construction of (a) three units of 150
32.
square  meters  (m2)  for  regional  offices  in  Anuradhapura;  (b)  quarters  for  the  divisional  forest
officers in Matara, Nuwara Eliya, and Ratnapura; (c) three offices (one at the range forest officer
level  and  two  at  the  beat  forest  officer  level);  and  (d)  an  auditorium  (400  m2)  at  the  Sri  Lanka
Forestry  Institute,  Nuwara  Eliya;  and  (ii)  improvement  of  the  access  road  to  Sinharaja  forest
reserve to enhance protection and facilitate ecotourism. Construction activities will generate noise
and dust that could be significant when close to a populated area. Therefore, selection of sites will
be important consideration to mitigate the impacts. Access roads for harvesting and reforestation
of  commercial  forest  plantations  in  the  upcountry  wet  and  dry  zones  should  be  designed  to
minimize soil erosion during rainy season.

33.
Improvement of the access road to Sinharaja forest reserve will result in better protection
of the resource, as it will facilitate inspections by senior FD officers. To avoid potential adverse
impacts  from  excessive  numbers  of  visitors,  FD  will  regulate  the  number  through  a  permit
system  that  will  be  monitored  closely.  Potential  impacts  of  erosion  resulting  from  road
improvement works can be avoided by ensuring adequate and well designed drainage along the

 62

road. Given the high rainfall in the area, the side and cross drainage will have to be constructed
in concrete to safeguard the environment and enhance longevity of the improved road.

e.

Potential Environmental Impacts from Project Operations

34.
No  major  adverse  environmental  impacts  are  expected  during  the  project  operational
phase.  The  socioeconomic  impacts  of  social  forestry  interventions  will  be  monitored  regularly.
Harvesting and reforestation of teak and eucalyptus plantations will have several adverse impacts.
The major impact due to harvesting and reforestation of eucalyptus plantations  in the upcountry
wet zone (Nuwara Eliya) is soil erosion. These impacts can be avoided by  adopting appropriate
and environmentally sound harvesting and reforestation techniques.

2.

Plantation Development and Mitigation Measures

a.

Environmental Enhancement and Proposed Mitigation Measures

Demarcation  and  marking  of  forest  reserve  boundaries  in  the  wet  zone,  using  concrete
35.
posts  and  participatory  forest  management,  are  expected  to  minimize  the  encroachment  into
forest. Protection forestry interventions will increase awareness among villagers in buffer zones of
targeted protection and conservation forests.

36.
Support services, training of MFE and FD field and head office staff, and reorganization of
FD  into  a  more  responsive  and  effective  structure  will  increase  the  performance  of  the  forest
sector.  Deregulation  of  cutting  and  transport  permits  for  timber  and  timber-based  products  will
reduce transaction and compliance costs that currently impede and distort productive investment
in the sector.

37.
A  workshop  with  farmers  in  the  targeted  area  generated  proposals  for  new  woodlot
models.  These  are  (i)  an  agroforestry  model  with  low-density  timber  trees  at  280  trees  per
hectare, which would retain 50 percent growing space for annual crops and would allow farmers
to plant about 20 fruit trees per hectare; and (ii) an agroforestry model designed to produce poles
and crops.

b.

Mitigation Measures for Harvesting and Reforestation Impacts

38.
Environmental impacts of harvesting and reforestation could be mitigated using low-impact
logging  techniques  and  reforestation  with  species  matched  to  site  characteristics  on  an
appropriate time schedule. Project interventions  will improve  forest  protection  and  conservation,
forest management, and forest plantation management.

Soil  erosion  is  the  anticipated  negative  environmental  impact  of  harvesting  and
39.
reforestation  of  eucalyptus  plantations  in  the  upcountry  wet  zone  is  soil  erosion.  This  can  be
mitigated  in  several  ways:  (i)  replanting  as  soon  as  possible  after  cutting  of  trees,  (ii)  avoiding
clear-cutting of large areas, (iii) limiting harvest to seasons of low rainfall, (iv) planning of felling to
minimize  log  skidding  and  avoiding  skidding  logs  parallel  to  the  slope,  (v)  stabilizing  skid  trails
after  use,  and  (vi)  using  animals  or  cable  logging  systems  instead  of  skidders  for  extraction.
Keeping  branches  and  other  debris  on  the  ground  can  mitigate  the  loss  of  nutrients  from  the
harvested area. Planting cover crops and adding fertilizer to compensate for nutrient loss is also
recommended.

40.
It is extremely important to monitor the harvesting and reforestation of teak and eucalyptus
plantations  to  ensure  that  loggers  and  harvesters  adhere  to  the  contracts  designed  in  the

 63

Appendix 9, page 8

management  plan  for  each  plantation,  to  minimize  environmental  impacts.  Frequency  of
monitoring  depends  on  site  conditions  and  the  extent  of  the  plantation.  A  trained  forester  will
monitor actual harvesting at least weekly.

c.

Overall Environmental Benefits

41.
The  main  benefits  expected  from  the  protection  forestry  interventions  and  public
awareness  and  extension  services  in  the  wet  zone  are  (i)  biodiversity,  and  soil  and  water
conservation  in  southwest  Sri  Lanka  (being  a  concentration  area  of  species  with  exceptional
levels of endemism and over 95 percent of the country’s threatened plant and animal species); (ii)
global importance (for conserving the world’s floristic diversity in the biodiversity problem area of
southwest Sri Lanka); (iii) awareness among peripheral communities and the general public of the
need  for  protection  and  conservation  forests;  and  (iv)  publication  of  information  relevant  to
conservation and biodiversity.

42.
The  sustainable  management  of  dry  zone  forest  reserves  under  the  social  forestry
interventions  will  increase  the  benefit  to  surrounding  communities.  Land  leased  for  AFWs  will
provide continuing income to farmers and discourage shifting cultivation. Improved management
of existing woodlots will provide incentives for continued smallholder management.

E.

Institutional Requirement and Environmental Monitoring Program

43.
MFE will be the Executing Agency and will coordinate and supervise policy and planning
reforms.  Implementation  of  field  and  technical  activities  will  be  conducted  through  FD.  An
appropriately  qualified  project  administrator  at  MFE  will  be  appointed  by  the  Government  for
effective implementation of the Project.

44.
A  project  management unit  (PMU)  will  be  constituted at  the  national  level.  The  project
director  will  head  the  PMU,  and  four  conservators  of  forests  will  be  members.  The  NPIU  will
assist the national project director by providing necessary technical and administrative support
to the conservators of forests in the field, to ensure effective and timely project implementation.
The  national  project  director,  with  assistance  of  the  PMU,  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall
coordination and planning of project inputs, outputs, and activities, including (i) coordination with
the  project  administrator  at  MFE,  and  with  other  projects  and  programs  in  the  sector;  (ii)
preparation  of  feasibility  study  reports  for  the  additional  subprojects  and  their  submission  to
ADB through the project administrator; (iii) assistance to the project administrator in drawing up
specifications  and  tender  documents  for  centralized  procurement  of  all  materials,  equipment,
and  vehicles  required  by  the  Project  as  well  as  for  the  survey,  delineation,  demarcation,  and
mapping  contracts;  (iv)  maintenance  and  submission  of  project  accounts  to  the  project
administrator  for  onward  submission  to  ADB;  (vi)  drafting  and  approval  of  contracts  within  its
authority  and  submission  of  contracts  not  within  its  authority  for  approval  to  appropriate
authorities;  (v)  review,  compilation,  and  submission  of  withdrawal  applications  and  other
documents  to  the  project  administrator  for  reimbursement  by  ADB;  (vii)  engagement  of
consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  the
Government  procedures;  (viii)  selection  of  participants  for  in-country  and  overseas  training  in
consultation  with  relevant  agencies;  and  (ix)  preparation  of  quarterly  and  annual  reports  for
submission to ADB and the appropriate Government agencies through the project administrator.
The government will ensure that the project administrator and national project director have the
assistance of administrative and other support staff to ensure efficient and effective delivery of
their responsibilities.

Findings and Recommendations

 47.

Using FD’s available biodiversity baseline data, the sixth year evaluation will include the

sample measurements of the permanent sample plots established by FD in the natural forests
within  the  SPAs.  This  activity  will  be  carried  out  in  collaboration  with  ADB’s  Protected  Area
Management and Wildlife  Conservation Project.  The  Project  will  support the  dry  zone farmers

and  is  to  be  undertaken  through  participatory  and  bottom-up  planning  approaches.  The

except under the commercial forest management.

G.

Conclusions

Commercial  plantation  activities  provide  increased  revenue  to  the  Government,  private
50.
sector  involvement  in  plantation  activities,  and  a  continuous  supply  of  wood  from  plantations.
Agroforestry  woodlot  activities  will  reduce  the  area  under  shifting  cultivation  and  provide
permanent  supplementary  income  to  farmers.  Improvements  to  existing  farmer  woodlots  will
increase  the  quality  and  quantity  of  wood  coming  to  the  market.  The  project  interventions  will
improve 
the  protection,  conservation,  and  management  of  high-priority  protection  and
conservation forests by reducing or halting the encroachments and illegal felling of timber.  It will
also  increase  the  awareness  of  conservation  among  peripheral  communities  and  the  general
public. If the Project is not implemented, the degradation of resources in these forest reserves will
continue. The proposed restructuring of FD will allow efficient management of forest resources in
the country.
