Appendix 10, page 1

SOCIAL ASSESSMENT

1.
The  forest  in  Sri  Lanka  is  being  seriously  depleted  through  overexploitation  by
commercial  interests  and  traditional  users,  and  through  inadequate  management  by  the
Forest  Department  (FD).  Most  of  the  forest’s  users  are  seriously  disadvantaged  by  their
poverty, lack of organization and information, lack of secured access to productive resources
such land and tress, lack of capital, and low levels of effective access to social services and
infrastructure. They have little direct access to markets, and are not organized to voice their
views  regarding  the  state  of  the  forest  or  its  management.  While  there  are  some
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  and  community-based  organizations  (CBOs)  are
working  among  the  forest  communities,  their  programs  show  lack  of  focus  on  sustainable
management of the forest  resources. Without dialogue and effective  working arrangements
between FD as the legal custodian of the forest and the forest-dependent communities who
are  mostly  poor,  the  current  alarming  trends  will  surely  continue.  Thus,  participatory
management  strategies  fully  involving  all  stakeholders  will  need  to  be  developed  and
implemented.

2.
Social  development  concerns  such  as  gender,  poverty,  and  participation  was
incorporated into all stages of project preparation. Poverty, gender, and participation issues
were basic to approaches used in socioeconomic and forest community data collection. The
three  core  subproject  areas  (Anuradhapura,  Badulla-Nuwara  Eliya  and  Ratnapura)  were
studied in detail. The social and economic issues were reflected in the selection and design
of the agroforestry and woodlot programs, land lease arrangements, land-use planning and
boundary survey.

A. 

Socioeconomic Profile of the Forest Communities in the Project Areas

3.
Anuradhapura  District  has  the  lowest  average  household  income  in  the  country
(SLRs2,600 per household per month compared to SLRs3,540 nationwide). Indicators of well
being  show  the  rural  dry  zone  population  to  be  vulnerable.  In  recent  surveys  (1997)  45
percent of children under the age of five were malnourished with 26 percent of them stunted.
Displacement  by  the  ethnic  conflict  in  the  north  and  east  of  the  country  as  well  as  the
dependence  on  farming  in  an  area  of  seasonal  and  varied  rainfall  has  created  vulnerable
populations. Although  land  is  relatively  abundant  with  only  83  people  per  square  kilometer
(km2),  parcels  of  irrigated  land  are  small.  In  areas  with  no  irrigation,  where  agriculture  is
highly  unreliable  most  households  depend  on  seasonal  wage  labor.  The  majority  of  the
targeted beneficiaries of social forestry interventions engage in shifting cultivation; about two
thirds have irrigated rice fields. The incidence of poverty is high. Of households sampled by
the project preparatory technical assistance team, 38 percent were at or below poverty  line
while  most  farmers  were  just  above  the  poverty  line.  The  farmer  households  are  highly
vulnerable  to  income  fluctuations  and  weather,  and  thus  70  percent  of  them  depend  on
Samurdhi welfare benefits. Most households have encroached on lands, but hesitant to put a
long-term  investment  in  them  for  productive  purposes.  Approximately  2,500  marginal  and
landless farm households will receive long-term leases to FD land for agroforestry plots and
farmer woodlots (2,500 ha) in Anuradhapura. Cost sharing will be provided for establishing of
the  tree  portion  of  the  leased  plots,  which  also  permits  annual  cropping.  The  provision  of
supplemental  income  from  the  wood  portion  of  these  plots  helps  to  reduce  household’s
vulnerability during years of poor rainfall. Greater participation of the community in land use
planning and decisions regarding forest reserve land use provides opportunities to invest in
improved grazing and other resources that can provide sources of income not dependent on
rainfall. Improved management of existing woodlots will target more than 2,000 participatory
project farmers who have planted teak.

 66

Appendix 10, page 2

Population density in Nuwara Eliya was 354 per km2  in 1981. Over 70 percent of the
4.
Nuwara  Eliya  population  and  over  80  percent  of  the  Badulla  population  are  engaged  in
agriculture,  fisheries,  or  forestry.  Population  pressure  in  highland  areas  has  led  to
encroachment  on  forest  reserves  for  vegetable  cultivation.  The  area  under  highland  tea  is
declining  as  eroded  land  is  moved  out  of  tea  production  and  new  planting  takes  place  for
lowland tea. Improved management of commercial plantations will target planting 1,155 ha of
eucalyptus and rehabilitating and managing an additional 1,381 ha of degraded plantations.
Social  forestry  interventions  are  limited  to  improvement  of  existing  farmer  woodlots  and
forest reserve buffer zone development in areas of high priority. Because of land scarcity and
the  need  to  protect  existing  forest  reserves,  FD  can  not  reserve  land  for  agroforestry  or
farmer woodlots. The project will benefit a total of 2,749 woodlot farmers through training and
marketing activities.

The population density in Ratnapura is 700 people/km2. Due to population pressure,
5.
the area under forest cover has been declining and with much of the remaining forest occurs
in  isolated  fragments.  The  region  is  highly  integrated  into  a  cash  crop  economy  with  tea,
rubber,  cinnamon,  and  coconut  as  principal  cash  crops.  The  beneficiaries  of  the  project  in
this  area  live  in  the  periphery  of  the  forest  reserves.  Most  of  them  cultivate  tea  and  other
cash crops,  such as  rubber and  cinnamon.  Although  the  incidence  of  poverty  is  low,  there
are pockets of poverty where 13 percent of the population are at or  below  the  poverty  line.
Most  residents,  regardless  of  income  levels,  have  encroached  on  lands.  The  high  labor
demand  for  tea  cultivation  and  steady  income  derived  from  tea  sales  has  reduced  rural
household dependency on forest product sales. However, many rural households continue to
harvest forest products, especially fuelwood and timber, for home consumption.

B. 

Gender and NGOs/CBOs Participation

In  the  dry  zone, households headed  by  women have fewer  wage  labor options  and
6.
are paid lower wages. Much of women’s income comes from agricultural activities. Training
for agroforestry plots, which seeks to stabilize shifting cultivation, will be targeted to women
farmers.  The  Project  will  ensure  equal  opportunity  for  women  and  men  to  sign/cosign  the
land  tenure  leases.  The  participation  of  NGOs  and  CBOs  in  the  project  preparation  and
implementation will enhance the effectiveness of project intervention to reduce poverty.

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS

A. 

Economic Analysis

1.
The  economic  analysis  for  the  Project  focuses  on  the  three  core  subprojects,  which  are
assumed to represent the range of physical conditions that prevail in the project areas and affect
development  and/or  rehabilitation  of  natural  forests  and  plantations.  Specific  field  interventions
were identified for implementation at each core subproject area (SPA) and were deemed replicable
in the agro-ecological zones of the sector project. The results of the economic analyses of the core
subprojects  are  deemed  sufficient  to  reflect  the  likely  range  of  returns  for  the  whole  project
including  the  SPAs.  The  economic  analysis  makes  the  following  assumptions  with  respect  to
foreign exchange rate, opportunity cost of labor, subproject costs, subproject benefits, and period
of analysis.

Economic Prices: Economic border prices (world price) are used in the economic
analysis.  Costs  and  benefits  were  broken  into  traded,  nontraded,  labor,  and  tax
factors and converted to world prices. For nontradables, a standard version factor of
0.9 was applied to derive economic prices, which is consistent with recent standard
conversion  factors  (SCFs)  applied  in  Asian  Development  Bank  and  World  Bank
projects. Economic prices were estimated by identifying the tradable (e.g., logs and
tea)  and  nontradable  output.  The  economic  price  of  timber  (Table  A11.1)  was
derived from the cost, insurance, and freight (CIF) price  in  local  currency adjusted
for  transport  and  handling  costs;  domestic  prices  were  adjusted  to  border  prices
using  the  SCF.  The  prices  for  internationally  traded  commodities  are  based  on
World  Bank  commodity  price  projections  and  adjusted  for  quality  differences.  The
economic prices  for  nontradables  were  derived  from  their  financial  prices  that  are
assumed to remain unchanged in real terms (constant 2000 prices).

Labor: The Government minimum wage rate is SLRs135 per day; however, casual
workers demand a daily wage of between SLRs185 per day (with food and transport
provided)  and  SLRs200  per  day  (excluding  food  and  transport)  during  peak
seasons. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.811 is applied to unskilled labor in line with
seasonal unemployment and underemployment in the SPAs.

A  financial  analysis  was  carried  out  to  demonstrate  the  financial  returns  that  could  be
3.
realized  from  investments  in  improving  the  present  management  and  utilization  of  natural

primary beneficiary. First, cultivated land is converted into a diversified agroforestry plot.  Second,
involving woodlot owners who have limited knowledge on silviculture or marketing of trees. Third,

 1.

Agroforestry Model

70

Appendix 11, page 3

This model (for 1 ha) is based on the planting of multipurpose trees (timber and fruit) in a
4.
low  density  that  enables  continued  annual  cropping.  Within  the  Sri  Lankan  context,  the  model
reflects  an  extended  version  of  the  home  garden.  In  the  “without”  project  analysis,  income  is
derived  from  swidden  farming2  systems,  that  is  converted  into  an  annual  land  rental  of
SLRs17,500/ha/yr. The annual rental is used to reflect the foregone income from such land when it
is  converted  from  swidden  farming.  The  output  of  the  model  is  based  on  production  of  annual
crops  (chilis,  gram,  corn,  soya,  and  millet),  with  medium-term  income  from  jack  fruit  trees,
mangoes, lime, tamarind, and margosa followed by longer term income from acacia poles and teak
logs.  The levels of financial rates of return vary marginally based on the proportion of family labor
relative  to  the  total  labor  demand.  A  financial  rate  of  return  of  14-16  percent  was  derived  under
differing hired labor scenarios with the higher rate associated with higher family labor input (Table
A11.4).

2.

Woodlot Model

The  woodlot  model  is based  on the current community woodlot model  that  assumes 1
5.
ha/individual  in  the  community.  Current  land  use  is based  on past  tree  planting  programs  where
community members were provided incentives to plant trees. Since then, there has been no follow
up and many of the stands are currently of poor form and mixed species some of which have little
economic  value.    There  is  also  uncertainty  about  the  ownership  of  such  plots  and  the  trees  on
them.    The  ownership  will  be  clarified  and  reinforced  through  the  issuance  of  long-term  leases,
along with input to maximize the value of the existing stand through pole harvesting and thinning.
Assistance  will  be  provided  in  harvesting  and  silviculture  training  and  the  establishment  of  a
second rotation.  The financial returns are estimated to be about 15 percent after incorporating the
likely market value of existing trees in the model (Table A11.5). The “without” project case is based
on delayed harvesting and no replanting.

3.

Buffer Zone Management

This  1  ha  model  is  used  as  an  indicative  buffer  zone  intensification  intervention  and  is
6.
based  on  the  actual  data  from  the  Tea  SmallHolder  Association  extension  program  for  tea
intensification. The “without” project analysis is based on a continuation of the  current  yields and
inputs. Under the “with” project case, yields are increased  in  response  to  improved  management
inputs and the use  of  mulches and fertilizer.  The  costs  of  implementing  the three-year  extension
program are excluded as there is currently no cost recovery for the extension program. The rates
of return are estimated to be 14 percent using the conservative estimate of yield response that has
been achieved to date in the program.

4.

Private Sector Concessions

The private sector concessionaire model is based on forming private sector corporate entity
7.
to  own  a  1,200  ha  forest  concession.    Under  the  “with”  project  scenario,  all  production  is
considered to be incremental as there is no production in a “without” project scenario.  Production
is  based  on  harvesting  of  the  existing  standing  stock  of  trees  over  a  27  year  period  on  the
concession,  and  then  through  the  reestablishment  of  a  second  rotation  from  which  preharvest
thinnings provide income. The operator pays stumpage on the existing timber only and then leases
the land under the second rotation, resulting in a FIRR of 13 percent that falls to 11 percent based
on assumed levels of financial gearing.
                                                  
2

Shifting agriculture based on a 3-year rotation due to increasing scarcity.
